answers.answer: Most likely they were simply diagnosed at a later time.  The family history of MS puts you at higher risk for MS.  Having one auto-immune (AI) disease (Hashimoto's) does increase the risk of other AI disease but most patients with Hashimoto's do not develop other AI disease -- sometimes earlier expression of AI disease (such as in your case, but more concerning if diagnosed as child/adolescent) may herald additional AI diseases.  I am vigilant in my hashi patients to screen for other AI diseases if they develop new symptoms/conditions.  The more common would be celiac sprue (inflammation of the small intestine due to gluten sensitivity) and Sjogren's (dry mouth/eyes) - less commonly: pernicious anemia (inability to absorb B12), diabetes mellitus, rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, MS, vitiligo and parathyroid underactivity.  The immune system itself is not impaired in its ability to fight infection.Hope that helps.

Thanks Dr. Mark - that really did help.  I was starting to get worried because I am so much younger than my mom and aunt.  I am currently trying to conceive my first child with my husband and I know autoimmune disease does not help.  My mom had no trouble conceiving three healthy children easily so I'm hoping to be like her. Thanks again for your help.

question: Hi Dr. Mark -  I was diagnosed as hypothyroid in July at age 28.  My mother and her sister were both also hypothyroid, both diagnosed in their mid forties.  My mother and I recently went to the endo and had our antibodies tested - both positive for Hashimoto's.  My questions are, does it mean anything that I became hypothyroid at a much younger age or were they both probably Hashimoto's at my age and just diagnosed at a later time?  I am nervous that this would put me more at risk for another autoimmune disease.  My mother also has multiple sclerosis.  Thank you in advance.
title: Earlier onsest of Hashimoto's than mother?
